title: About
text:
Here are my core principles which guide my work and life:

Useful. If it’s not useful, then what’s the point?
Clear. I loathe unnecessary complexity,
Respectful. We don’t all share the same values, and beliefs. That’s a good thing.
Resourceful. Wasted resources here could have been used elsewhere.
Humble. I’ve been wrong before, and I’ll be wrong again.

title: About
text:
Rolling list of interests

[Nov 2024] I’m pretty into anything cyberpunk / synthwave these days. Especially Gunship. For that reason I updated this site to use the “Cyberpunk aesthetic” vapor theme. I’m sure I’ll change it to something more basic when the novelty wears off.

[Nov 12, 2024] It wore off.

title: Experience
text:
I obtained a PhD in Cognitive Psychology from the University of Basel in Basel, Switzerland and the Max Planck Institute for Human Development in Berlin, Germany within the Center for Adaptive Rationality lead by Dr. Ralph Hertwig. The focus of my PhD research was on adaptive decision making rules in individuals and groups. See Phillips, Hertwig, Kareev & Avrahami, 2014 for an example publication from my PhD.



Prior to my PhD, I obtained a Masters in Psychology at Ohio University at the department of Social Judgment and Behavioral Decision making under Dr. Claudia Gonzalez-Vallejo. The focus of my Master’s thesis was on the role of experiences and expert advice on decisions.



I obtained BA in Mathematics from Grinnell College. My undergraduate coursework focused on probability and statistics and behavioral decision making.

title: Experience
text:
I obtained a PhD in Cognitive Psychology from the University of Basel in Basel, Switzerland and the Max Planck Institute for Human Development in Berlin, Germany within the Center for Adaptive Rationality lead by Dr. Ralph Hertwig. The focus of my PhD research was on adaptive decision making rules in individuals and groups. See Phillips, Hertwig, Kareev & Avrahami, 2014 for an example publication from my PhD.



Prior to my PhD, I obtained a Masters in Psychology at Ohio University at the department of Social Judgment and Behavioral Decision making under Dr. Claudia Gonzalez-Vallejo. The focus of my Master’s thesis was on the role of experiences and expert advice on decisions.



I obtained BA in Mathematics from Grinnell College. My undergraduate coursework focused on probability and statistics and behavioral decision making.

title: Experience
text:
Experience

Academia

Pre-Doctoral Researcher, Ohio University
As a pre-doctoral researcher at Ohio University, I taught multiple university courses in statistics and research methods for psychology undergraduate students.


Pre-Doctoral Researcher, University of Basel
As a pre-doctoral researcher at the University of Basel, I taught undergraduate and masters level seminars in research methods.


Researcher, University of Konstanz






Publishing an e-book on statistical programming with R



I converted my teaching materials on statistical programming with R into a free e-book “YaRrr! The Pirate’s Guide to R” that is still used by students and researchers around the world


Following the completion of my PhD, I completed a research position at at the University of Konstanz in Konstanz, Germany in the department of Social Psychology and Decision Sciences lead by Dr. Wolfgang Gaissmaier. There I taught Bachelors, Masters, and PhD-level courses in statistical programming with R, and decision making. I ultimately translated my statistical programming teaching materials into a free e-book “YaRrr! The Pirate’s Guide to R”. The book was, and still is, used by many students and researchers around the world to learn statistical programming with R. The book is still available at https://bookdown.org/ndphillips/YaRrr/.
In addition to teaching


Researcher, University of Basel
I also completed a post-doctoral research position at the University of Basel in the department of Economic Psychology lead by Dr. Joerg Rieskamp.



Industry
Here is a selection of my work experience. See my LinkedIn page for a more detailed history.


CTO & Co-Founder, Plinth Analytics






From $0 to $1M in 1.5 years of bootstrapped development



In just 1.5 years, we went from two people with an idea to a team of 5 and $1M in revenue across multiple pharma and healthtech clients.


Most recently, I was the CTO and Co-Founder of Plinth Analytics, a company that helps healthcare organizations make better decisions with messy healthcare data. In this role, I led the development of our data science platform and worked with our customers to understand their needs and deliver solutions that helped reduce costs and generate new use-cases for EHR, claims and genomic data.
I am currently a Quantitative Scientist at Flatiron Health, where I work on real-world data science problems in oncology.

CTO, Co-Founder, Plinth Analytics

The thrill of a lifetime with my co-founder and friend Kieran Mace, along with rockstar data scientists Nicole Mirea, Parker Barnes |

Quantitative Scientist, Flatiron Health

Best culture and teams I’ve ever been a part of. Grateful to people like Olivier Humblet, Caleb Jordan, Daniel Obeng, Conal Scanlon, John Zielinksi (and so many more) for teaching and supporting me during my time there.|

Real World Data Scientist, Roche

Where I learned how real world science is done by teams and what a great manager looks like (thank you Robert Walls)

Postdoctoral Researcher, University of Basel
Postdoctoral Researcher, University of Konstanz

Developing FFTrees with Hansjoerg Neth and Wolfgang Gaissmaier was a turning point for the rest of my career

Pre-Doctoral Researcher, Max Planck Institute for Human Development

Paradise for decision-making research thanks to Gerd Gigerenzer, Ralph Hertwig and where I discovered a love of R with my fellow PhD student Dirk Wulff|

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
I am a professional learner and solution designer driven to help people and organizations solve challenging problems and tell impact stories from data. I am passionate about creating tools and systems that reduce waste and empower people to make better decisions.
I am most well known for Healthcare Data Science, Statistical Programming with R, and Medical Decision Making.

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
Edcuation

PhD, Cognitive Psychology, University of Basel, Basel, Switzerland
MS, Quantitative Psychology, Ohio University, Athens, OH
BA, Mathematics, Grinnell College, Grinnell, IA

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
Experience
I have over 10 years of experience across academia and industry, from large corporations (e.g.; Roche) to small start-ups (e.g.; Plinth Analytics), as a research scientist, statistical software developer, people manager, team lead, chief technology officer, and co-founder. While I have spent most of my career create technical solutions, I leverage my background in decision making psychology to ensure that every solution I design, and every presentation I deliver, are practical and engaging and will actually impact flesh and blood decision makers. At a personal level, I aim to be source of contagious enthusiasm and create a legacy at every organization I’m privileged to be a part of.
See my About page or on LinkedIn to learn more about my experience.

title: Nathaniel D. Phillips, PhD
text:
Projects and Publications
While most of my professional healthcare work is proprietary, here is a selection of my open source projects, presentations, and publications.

Publications
See my Google Scholar page for a partial list of publications. Note that most of my healthcare publications are not listed here.


Presentations







FlatironKitchen: How we overhauled a Frankensteinian SQL workflow with the Tidyverse, RStudio Conf, 2019
FFTrees: An R package to create, visualise and use fast and frugal decision trees, useR!, 2017
Using R to Derive Robust Insights from Real-World Health Care Data, R/Pharma, 2022



Open Source Projects


FFTrees. The R package FFTrees creates, visualizes and evaluates fast-and-frugal decision trees (FFTs) for solving binary classification tasks, using the algorithms and methods described in Phillips, Neth, Woike & Gaissmaier.
yarrr. The yarrr package is a collection of tools for teaching introductory statistics and data science with R. It focuses on making complex statistical concepts accessible to beginners and includes a suite of functions for data visualization and statistical testing.
The Pirate’s Guide to R is a book that teaches R programming to beginners. It is designed to be accessible to people with no prior programming experience and is used in introductory statistics courses at universities around the world.

title: Tips
text:
Here are some of my favorite resources - a mixture of books, tutorials, blogs, podcasts and YouTube, and software.
I’ll do my best to keep this updated but it will almost certainly be out of date by the time you read it. If you have any suggestions for resources I should add, please let me know.

title: Tips
text:
Books
Here are some of my favorite books

The Design of Everyday Things, Donald A. Norman

As applicable to programming as it is to the design of doors

The First 90 Days, Michael D. Watkins

A great resource for anyone starting a new job - recommended by Lura Long

The Checklist Manifesto, Atul Gawande

Gawande is one of my favorite writers at the intersection of science and medicine.

How big things get done, Bent Flyvbjerg, Dan Gardner

Should be required reading for anyone working on projects with teams - recommended by Nicole Mirea

R for Data Science, Hadley Wickham, Garrett Grolemund

A great resource for learning R

Writing R Packages, Hadley Wickham

The bible of R package development

title: Tips
text:
Tutorials
Here are some of my favorite online tutorials and guides

Survival Analysis in R, Emily Zabor

A great introduction to survival analysis in R (by a fellow Grinnellian!)

title: Tips
text:
Blogs
Here are some blogs I like by companies and people I admire

Danielle Navarro, Danielle Navarro is a cognitive scientist who writes about statistics and programming in R.
Emily Riederer. Emily Riederer is a leading voice in modern data science across multiple languages and platforms.
Emily Zabor. Emily Zabor is an expert in epidemiology and public health who writes about data science and statistics in R

title: Tips
text:
Podcasts and YouTube
Here are some of my favorite podcasts and YouTube channels

Cautionary Tales by Tim Harford | Wrong Tools Cost Lives|

title: Tips
text:
Software
Here are some of my favorite software tools

Notion. I use Notion for everything from project management to personal notes
RStudio. My favorite IDE for data science development
GitHub Copilot. Copilot is spectatular, especially using the RStudio Copilot Plugin
Quarto. The successor to my beloved RMarkdown which powers just about every document I create (including this website).
